Better Enums

Fast, intuitive enums for C++

Open-source under the BSD license

Welcome to the Better Enums tutorials! The code in this tutorial forms a valid program, which you can download and play with.

Compile-time usage

When used with C++11, Better Enums are generated entirely during compilation. All the data is available for use by your own constexpr functions. The examples in this tutorial aren't very useful, but read the following tutorials to get an idea of what can be done. Here, you will see the basics.

#include <iostream>

#define BETTER_ENUMS_CONSTEXPR_TO_STRING

#include <enum.h>

ENUM(Channel, int, Red = 1, Green = 2, Blue = 3)

constexpr Channel      channel = Channel::Green;
constexpr int          value = channel._to_integral();

constexpr const char   *name = channel._to_string();
constexpr Channel      parsed = Channel::_from_string("Red");

All of the above are computed during compilation. You can do apparently useless things such as:

constexpr size_t length(const char *s, size_t index = 0)
{
    return s[index] == '\0' ? index : length(s, index + 1);
}

constexpr size_t    length_of_name_of_second_constant =
    length(Channel::_names()[1]);

int main()
{
    std::cout << length_of_name_of_second_constant << std::endl;

    return 0;
}

Which prints "5", the length of "Green". That 5 was also computed during compilation.

This is the last tutorial! Return to the main page for other resources.
